page.title: 02LANDSCAPE, DEEPCAR/WORTLEY
page.content: The scenery in the Deepcar area is created by the erosive action of the Rivers Don and its tributary the Porter (little Don). They have cut deep parallel valleys along the scarplines. From the confluence at Deepcar, the Don flows down the wooded valley, with Wharncliffe Crags 150 metres above it, towards Sheffield. Viewed from the A629 near Wortley, through the gap formed by the Don, the escarpment of Hunshelf Bank is clearly visible, the scarp slope facing Deepcar and the south-west. Similarly Wharncliffe Rocks represent the scarp face and the Chase area to the A629 the dip slope. Don Field river cliff cross section _ clays, coal shales(incl.fossil mussels), sandstone. Outcrops of millstone grit(hard sandstone) at Wharncliffe Crags and Townend Common.
